diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome

diagnoses.name: Measles
diagnoses.description: A highly infectious viral illness known to cause fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and a characteristic rash.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body. It's more common in children. Symptoms include fever, rash, swelling, and redness of palms, soles, lips, and throat.

diagnoses.name: Rubella (German Measles)
diagnoses.description: A contagious viral infection best known by its distinctive red rash. It is usually mild in children but can have more serious consequences in adults, such as arthritis and fetal harm.

diagnoses.name: Infectious mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Often called mono or the kissing disease, this infection is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus and produces fatigue, a sore throat, fever, and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection usually spread by sexual contact that starts as a painless sore — typically on your genitals, rectum, or mouth. Secondary syphilis can present with rash and mucous membrane lesions.

diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, serious disorder of your skin and mucous membranes. It's usually a reaction to a medication or an infection. Symptoms may include fever, sore mouth, and a painful rash.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet fever
diagnoses.description: An infection that can develop in people who have strep throat. Characterized by a bright red rash, fever, and sore throat.

diagnoses.name: Toxic shock syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening complication of certain bacterial infections. Symptoms include sudden high fever, rash, low blood pressure, and peeling skin.

diagnoses.name: Drug reactions
diagnoses.description: Adverse reactions to medications can vary greatly and may include symptoms like rashes, swelling, and organ damage.

diagnoses.name: Adenovirus infection
diagnoses.description: A type of viral infection that can affect the tissues linings of respiratory tract, eyes, intestines, urinary tract, and nervous system. Symptoms may include pink eye, fever, and throat discomfort.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Dermatologic conditions like eczema or psoriasis with secondary infection

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. It can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs, leading to a wide range of symptoms including arthropathy, pleural and pericardial effusions, skin rashes, and, in severe cases, delirium.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. In severe cases, it can cause pleural effusion and pericardial effusion. Skin manifestations can include erythematous-violaceous rashes, and systemic symptoms may lead to delirium.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An uncommon inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. It can also cause joint issues (arthropathy), pleural effusions, and in rare cases, pericardial effusion. Systemic symptoms can progress to delirium.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that displays features of three other connective tissue diseases—lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis—including arthropathy, erythematous-violaceous rashes, pleural and pericardial effusions. Neuropsychiatric symptoms can include delirium.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, mostly the lungs and lymph glands. Skin lesions, arthritis, pleural effusion, and pericardial effusion can occur. Neurosarcoidosis can lead to delirium.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause a variety of symptoms depending on the organs affected. It can present with skin rashes (erythematous-violaceous), joint pain (arthropathy), pleural effusion, and pericardial effusion. Severe cases may affect the brain, potentially leading to delirium.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the inner lining of the heart chambers and heart valves. It can cause arthropathy through immune complex deposition, erythematous-violaceous lesions like Osler's nodes, pleural effusion, and pericardial effusion. Severe cases can progress to delirium.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: Caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi and transmitted to humans through the bite of infected black-legged ticks. It can cause erythematous-violaceous rashes (erythema migrans), arthritic symptoms, neurologic symptoms including delirium, and in rare cases, pleural or pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.description: A group of rare, chronic autoimmune diseases that involve the hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues. It can cause arthralgia, pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, and in some cases, skin manifestations and delirium due to systemic involvement.

diagnoses.name: Viral Myocarditis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the heart muscle typically caused by viral infections. It can lead to pericardial effusion, and in severe cases, systemic symptoms including delirium. Joint pain and skin symptoms are less common but can occur in associated syndromes or as part of a broader viral syndrome.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Central nervous system infections (e.g., meningitis, encephalitis)
Viral Infections (e.g., Dengue Fever, Zika Virus)
Lupus Nephritis specifically (subset of SLE with kidney involvement)
Viral Infections (e.g., Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C)
Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) with extraintestinal manifestations

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can affect multiple systems including the nervous system (leading to psychosis and seizures), kidneys (leading go proteinuria), and the heart (resulting in pericarditis and pericardial effusion).

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This rheumatologic condition presents with features of several systemic diseases, including SLE. It can cause neurological symptoms, renal involvement, and cardiac issues similar to those described.

diagnoses.name: Viral Myocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: Certain viral infections can lead to myocarditis, which can be associated with pericarditis and pericardial effusion. Secondary effects can include renal involvement and, in rare cases, neurological manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.rationale: Though less common in developed countries, it's a complication of untreated strep throat leading to various symptoms, including carditis (which may manifest as pericarditis). Neurological symptoms (Sydenham chorea) can be confused with seizures.

diagnoses.name: Uremic Encephalopathy
diagnoses.rationale: A severe manifestation of kidney failure which can present with proteinuria. It leads to an accumulation of toxins affecting the brain (psychosis, seizures) and can indirectly affect the heart.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: A multisystem granulomatous disease, which can involve the central nervous system (causing seizures), kidneys (proteinuria), and heart (pericarditis).

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: Certain drugs can induce a lupus-like syndrome, featuring some of the systemic effects of SLE, including cardiac and renal symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Poststreptococcal Glomerulonephritis
diagnoses.rationale: Following a strep infection, this condition impacts the kidneys (proteinuria) and can have associated rare complications affecting the heart and nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune disorder that can lead to blood clots in both arteries and veins, which can indirectly affect the heart and kidneys, possibly resulting in neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: Infectious endocarditis can lead to a wide array of symptoms including heart (pericardial effusion), renal involvement (proteinuria), and in cases with embolic phenomena, neurological manifestations.

diagnoses: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis)
Infectious diseases (e.g., bacterial, viral, fungal infections)
Viral Infection (e.g., Parvovirus B19, Epstein-Barr virus)
Infectious Diseases (e.g., viral, bacterial infections causing lymphadenitis and hyperthermia)
Autoimmune Disorders (e.g., conditions that might lead to skin manifestations like dyshydrotic eczema)
Gastrointestinal Disorders (e.g., conditions leading to hemorrhoids)
Metabolic Disorders (conditions that can cause dysgeusia)
Endocrine Disorders (conditions that might lead to hyperthermia or dysgeusia)
Hematologic Diseases (conditions that might lead to lymphadenitis or impact skin health)
Neurological Disorders (conditions that could potentially cause dysgeusia)
Inflammatory Diseases (conditions leading to inflammation that could result in symptoms like lymphadenitis or eczema)

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disorder affecting multiple parts of the body, including the blood vessels which could explain the aneurysms and oral pain.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder that causes inflammation of the blood vessels in your nose, sinuses, throat, lungs, and kidneys, potentially leading to sinutitis.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth but can also lead to lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body, potentially explaining the diverse symptoms.

diagnoses.name: IgG4-Related Disease
diagnoses.description: A fibro-inflammatory condition marked by tumefactive lesions, which can lead to the symptoms mentioned including lymphadenopathy and sinusitis.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Cancer of the lymphatic system, which can cause lymphadenopathy and swelling in various parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, often starting in the lungs or lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Giant Cell Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease of blood vessels that can lead to headaches, jaw pain, and potentially aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Takayasu's Arteritis
diagnoses.description: A rare type of vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessels) that can lead to aneurysms, and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, it can lead to symptoms like oral pain, bloating, and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells. These excess cells thicken the blood, slowing its flow, and can cause complications such as tinnitus and vision issues. Polycythemia vera can also lead to abnormal blood sugar levels (glycemic lability) due to its effects on overall health.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth. It can also cause lymphadenitis (swelling of the lymph nodes) due to chronic immune activation. While it is less commonly associated with polycythemia or tinnitus directly, its systemic nature means it can affect the body in various ways, potentially influencing blood viscosity and hearing.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the bone marrow and the blood. Patients may experience an increase in white blood cells, which can lead to symptoms such as fatigue, night sweats, and unintentional weight loss. While not directly linked to tinnitus or dry eyes, the systemic effects of the disease can contribute to a wide range of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: While typically characterized by a low red blood cell count, in some cases, it can paradoxically lead to polycythemia as the body tries to compensate for low hemoglobin. Symptoms can include fatigue and weakness, and in severe cases, it can affect oxygen delivery to the brain, potentially leading to tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition that affects how the body processes blood sugar (glucose). Glycemic lability is a direct symptom of poorly controlled diabetes. While not directly associated with polycythemia, tinnitus, lymphadenitis, or dry eyes, the systemic nature of diabetes means it can affect many bodily systems and lead to a wide range of health issues.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. While known for its joint symptoms, it can also cause systemic symptoms such as dry eyes (part of Keratoconjunctivitis Sicca), and lymphadenitis. Blood cell abnormalities can also occur in rheumatoid arthritis, potentially contributing to an atypical polycythemia.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions affecting thyroid function, such as hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism, can lead to a wide array of symptoms, potentially affecting blood sugar control, and by extension, causing lability in glycemic levels. While not commonly associated with polycythemia or tinnitus directly, the impact on metabolic rate and overall health can lead to varied symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: Caused by the Borrelia burgdorferi bacterium, Lyme disease can cause a variety of symptoms, depending on the stage of the infection. Early signs may include fever, headache, fatigue, and skin rash. If untreated, it can lead to more severe problems, including neurological disorders (potentially affecting hearing as tinnitus) and arthritis. It is less commonly associated with polycythemia, but its wide range of effects can mimic or contribute to symptoms of other conditions.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: A disease involving abnormal collections of inflammatory cells that form lumps known as granulomas. These granulomas can affect various organs in the body, including the eyes and lymph nodes, potentially resulting in dry eyes and lymphadenitis. Sarcoidosis is less commonly linked to polycythemia and tinnitus but can affect multiple organ systems and lead to a broad range of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.description: A cancer that forms in a type of white blood cell called a plasma cell, which helps you fight infections by making antibodies. Multiple myeloma affects the bone marrow and can cause a wide range of symptoms, including bone pain, weakness, and fatigue. While it is primarily known for affecting white blood cell levels, it can also lead to increased red blood cell production (polycythemia) due to its impact on the bone marrow.

diagnoses.name: Hemochromatosis
diagnoses.description: Hemochromatosis is a disorder where too much iron builds up in your body, sometimes causing hyperferritinemia. This can indirectly affect heart health and may contribute to conditions such as takotsubo cardiomyopathy. The disease might also cause nausea but is less likely to directly cause decreased immunoglobulins or dysphagia.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: SLE is an autoimmune disease that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including nausea and decreased immunoglobulins due to its impact on the body's immune system. While less commonly, it can also affect the heart, potentially leading to conditions like takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

diagnoses.name: Amyloidosis
diagnoses.description: Amyloidosis occurs when substances called amyloid proteins build up in your organs. Amyloid buildup can lead to heart conditions such as takotsubo cardiomyopathy, and it can affect the gastrointestinal tract, causing nausea and dysphagia. It might also impact the immune system, affecting immunoglobulin levels.

diagnoses.name: Common Variable Immunodeficiency (CVID)
diagnoses.description: CVID is an immunodeficiency disorder that can decrease immunoglobulin levels, making it harder to fight off infections. Patients may experience gastrointestinal symptoms including nausea. While less directly associated, stress or illness related to CVID might trigger takotsubo cardiomyopathy in susceptible individuals.

diagnoses.name: Gastric cancer
diagnoses.description: Gastric cancer can lead to nausea and dysphagia due to the tumor's presence in the stomach or esophagus. While it is less directly connected to hyperferritinemia, elevated ferritin levels can sometimes occur in cancer. Gastric cancer's indirect effects on the body's stress and health might contribute to takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

diagnoses.name: Iron Overload Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions leading to iron overload, including multiple blood transfusions or dysregulated iron absorption, can cause hyperferritinemia. Nausea is a common symptom of excessive iron in the body, and the stress from overload might increase the risk of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: Sarcoidosis is an inflammatory disease that often affects the lungs, but can also influence heart health, potentially leading to cardiomyopathies such as takotsubo. It can cause dysphagia if it affects the gastrointestinal system. Hyperferritinemia may occur as part of an acute phase reactant response.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.description: Multiple Myeloma is a type of blood cancer that can cause decreased immunoglobulins due to abnormal plasma cells in the bone marrow. It can also lead to hyperferritinemia. The stress on the body from battling this cancer might trigger takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: Hypothyroidism, especially when severe, can lead to decreased immunoglobulins. Patients might experience nausea and, less commonly, dysphagia due to myxedema. The metabolic stress from untreated hypothyroidism may contribute to the development of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

diagnoses.name: Graft-vs-Host Disease
diagnoses.description: This disease can occur after a stem cell or bone marrow transplant, causing decreased immunoglobulins due to immune system suppression or attack on the host body. It may cause nausea and dysphagia if the gastrointestinal tract is affected. The overall stress and immune dysregulation might predispose individuals to takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reason: Can cause weight gain and menstrual irregularities that could lead to miscarriage, and may indirectly contribute to oral pain due to effects on tissues.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.reason: PCOS can cause weight gain and is associated with a higher risk of miscarriage. While oral pain and hemorrhoids are not direct symptoms, hormonal imbalances can contribute to various systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Gestational Diabetes
diagnoses.reason: Though primarily associated with high blood sugar during pregnancy, it can result in weight gain and has an increased risk of miscarriage. Oral pain is not directly linked but can be affected by changes in health status.

diagnoses.name: Obesity
diagnoses.reason: Obesity itself can lead to weight gain (obviously) and can increase the risk of miscarriages due to hormonal imbalances. Obesity is also a risk factor for hemorrhoids due to increased abdominal pressure.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.reason: While primarily affecting the lungs and causing a chronic cough, COPD can lead to weight gain due to reduced activity levels. However, it is less directly associated with miscarriages and oral pain.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.reason: May contribute to miscarriages and can cause oral pain (via mouth ulcers), but the connection with weight gain and hemorrhoids is less direct, often resulting from dietary issues that may also lead to weight gain.

diagnoses.name: Thrombophilia
diagnoses.reason: This is a condition of increased tendency to form blood clots, which can lead to miscarriages. People with thrombophilia may also develop hemorrhoids due to blood clots in the area. There is no direct link to weight gain or oral pain.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.reason: Can lead to weight gain due to changes in appetite or eating habits. Depression doesn't directly cause miscarriages or oral pain but can be indirectly related due to neglect of health.

diagnoses.name: Heart Failure
diagnoses.reason: Can lead to weight gain due to fluid retention. While not directly linked to miscarriages, oral pain or hemorrhoids, it impacts overall health significantly.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reason: Can lead to weight gain and is associated with a risk of miscarriage due to poor blood sugar control. Diabetes can also contribute to oral health issues, including pain, due to its effects on blood vessels and nerves.

diagnoses.name: Common Variable Immune Deficiency (CVID)
diagnoses.description: CVID is an immune system disorder that increases susceptibility to infection along with possible complications including angioedema and autoimmune disorders.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS)
diagnoses.description: CFS is a complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue, fibromyalgia-like pain, chemical sensitivities, and sometimes palpitations or other autonomic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: MCAS involves inappropriate mast cell activation and can result in a wide range of symptoms including chemical sensitivities, angioedema, and an increased risk of infections.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: SLE is an autoimmune disease that can cause widespread inflammation and tissue damage in affected organs, leading to chemical sensitivities, increased susceptibility to infections, and potentially fibrosis in various organs.

diagnoses.name: Hypereosinophilic Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of blood disorders characterized by an overproduction of eosinophils, leading to inflammation and possibly fibrosis of organs, increased susceptibility to infections, and occasionally, angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder resulting in recurrent attacks of severe swelling (angioedema). Patients might also experience abdominal pain and airway obstruction.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease characterized by hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues (fibrosis). Some patients experience heart palpitations due to cardiac involvement.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Environmental Intolerance (IEI)
diagnoses.description: Also known as Multiple Chemical Sensitivity (MCS), IEI is characterized by chronic symptoms attributed to low-level chemical exposures. Symptoms often include chemical sensitivities and can also lead to an increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Cardiac Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can affect various organs but when it affects the heart (cardiac sarcoidosis), it can lead to fibrosis of heart tissues, palpitations, and potentially lethal arrhythmias.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency Diseases (PIDDs)
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders caused by defects in the immune system's components, leading to an increased susceptibility to infections. Patients may also experience complications like autoimmunity or angioedema.

diagnoses: Blepharospasm may be primary or a symptom of a broader condition. Considering the combination of symptoms, including blepharospasm, xerosis (dry skin), mood lability, and pneumonia, a list of possible diagnoses can go beyond just 10 and may include a range of disorders. However, narrower to a more typical range of possibilities influenced by these particular symptoms, here are speculative diagnoses that could be considered by healthcare professionals:
Secondary pneumonia due to immune system compromise
note: This list is speculative and for educational purposes only. Accurate diagnosis requires comprehensive evaluation by healthcare professionals, including history, physical examination, and possibly laboratory and imaging studies. The presence of these symptoms warrants a thorough assessment by a medical professional.

diagnoses: Dental Abscess with Spread of Infection
Autoimmune diseases (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus)

diagnoses.name: Menopause
reasoning: Vulvodynia and osteoporosis are more common in postmenopausal women due to decreased estrogen levels.

diagnoses.name: Primary Hyperparathyroidism
reasoning: Can cause osteoporosis and contributes to dyslipidemia.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
reasoning: Can lead to hyperlipidemia (dyslipidemia) and may exacerbate osteoporosis.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren's Syndrome
reasoning: Autoimmune disease that could potentially explain the nasal congestion (secondary to dryness), and has been associated with vulvodynia.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Rhinosinusitis
reasoning: Explains nasal congestion and epistaxis but indirectly associated with the other conditions.

diagnoses.name: Familial Hypercholesterolemia
reasoning: Explains dyslipidemia. Indirect association with osteoporosis through potential cardiovascular complications influencing overall health.

diagnoses.name: Obesity
reasoning: Can be a contributing factor to dyslipidemia. Mechanical factors associated with obesity could potentially play a role in vulvodynia symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Liver Disease
reasoning: Can lead to dyslipidemia and is a risk factor for osteoporosis.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin D Deficiency
reasoning: Can lead to osteoporosis and has an indirect association with dyslipidemia.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Allergies
reasoning: Could explain nasal congestion and possible epistaxis due to chronic irritation. Allergies have loose associations but can impact overall inflammatory status, possibly influencing other conditions.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) with comorbid anxiety
Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) with respiratory manifestations
Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction
Autoimmune Diseases such as Sjogren's Syndrome
Dermatologic conditions (e.g., psoriasis leading to alopecia)
Bacterial or viral infections (leading to lymphadenopathy and lymphadenitis)
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) due to chronic cough association
Chronic Urticaria (for physical symptoms like angioedema and hypersensitivity reactions)
Autoimmune Disorders (Certain autoimmune conditions could lead to symptoms like angioedema, hypersensitivity reactions, and potentially impact mental health)
Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) (could explain cysts, miscarriage, and has been linked with depression)
Thyroid Disorders (e.g., hypothyroidism can lead to depression, menstrual irregularities, miscarriage)
Hereditary Angioedema (explains angioedema, and the stress of managing a chronic condition could contribute to depression)
Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) (can cause a wide range of physical symptoms including those listed, and can also affect mental health)
Cushing's Syndrome (can lead to depression, weight gain, and can sometimes be associated with cysts)
Fibromyalgia (has been associated with a higher incidence of depression and other symptoms might align under chronic pain and hypersensitivity)
Hypertensive heart and chronic kidney disease
Neurological Disorders (specific conditions that could lead to hyperthermia and palpitations)

diagnoses.name: Reactive Thrombocytosis
diagnoses.description: An elevated platelet count, which may occur as a reactive process to another condition such as infection (pneumonia, urinary tract infection), inflammation, or cancer.

diagnoses.name: Paraneoplastic Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of clinical syndromes associated with malignancy, including hypercalcemia, thrombocytosis, and other systemic symptoms, without the cancer directly causing the symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Endocarditis
diagnoses.description: A microbial infection of the heart valves or endocardium that may cause a wide variety of systemic symptoms, including fevers, joint pain, and heart abnormalities, sometimes accompanied by thrombocytosis as part of an inflammatory response.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune condition that primarily affects joints leading to inflammation and pain, which can also cause systemic symptoms including lung involvement (interstitial lung disease) and can occasionally present with Sjögren's syndrome, leading to hyperthyroidism.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organ systems including skin, joints, kidneys, blood cells, and can cause thrombocytosis as well as other hematologic abnormalities.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A blood disorder characterized by the overproduction of red blood cells by the bone marrow. It can lead to an elevated platelet count (thrombocytosis) and is associated with an increased risk of blood clots. It can sometimes present with hyperthyroidism due to increased metabolic demand.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts in the blood-forming cells of the bone marrow and invades the blood. It can cause elevated platelet counts, fatigue, night sweats, and bone pain.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease characterized by the formation of granulomas in multiple organs, including the lungs (pneumonia-like symptoms), skin, and lymph nodes. It can also affect the joints and the urinary tract.

diagnoses.name: Thyroiditis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the thyroid gland, which can cause hyperthyroidism in early stages. This condition can be associated with a variety of systemic symptoms depending on the type and severity of inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease
diagnoses.description: A term for two conditions (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis) that are characterized by chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract. Peripheral arthritis, erythema nodosum, and other systemic symptoms including thrombocytosis can occur.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Acute Abdominal Conditions (e.g., Acute Intestinal Obstruction, Appendicitis)
Chemical Poisoning (e.g., from toxic plants or mushrooms)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) - including Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis
Food Allergies or Intolerances (e.g., lactose intolerance)
Gastrointestinal disorders causing abdominal cramps and secondary systemic symptoms
Acute viral upper respiratory tract infection (Common cold)
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) with acute exacerbation
Heart failure with acute pulmonary edema
Acute Diabetic emergencies – such as Diabetic Ketoacidosis
Allergic reaction to food or medication
Medication side effect or adverse reaction

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden weakness, numbness, difficulty speaking, headache, and vision problems.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). The immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers, causing communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body. Symptoms can include fatigue, numbness and weakness, electric shock sensations with certain neck movements, tremors, lack of coordination, and vision problems.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraines are a type of headache characterized by intense pain, sensitivity to light and sounds, and often nausea and vomiting. Migraines with aura include visual disturbances (scotomas, flashing lights) and other neurological symptoms (such as weakness, numbness, and speech difficulties) that typically precede the headache.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. A TIA usually lasts only a few minutes and doesn't cause permanent damage. Symptoms can include weakness, numbness, confusion, difficulty speaking, and sudden vision problems.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor is a mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Many different types of brain tumors exist. Symptoms can vary greatly depending on the brain tumor's size, location, and growth rate. Common symptoms include headaches, seizures, numbness, speech problems, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is an inflammation of the membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. The swelling from meningitis typically triggers symptoms such as headache, fever, and a stiff neck. In severe cases, it can lead to confusion, seizures, difficulty speaking, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Intracerebral Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: This is when there is a sudden bleeding into the tissues of the brain, within its ventricles, or into the subarachnoid space. It can occur spontaneously or as a result of trauma. Symptoms often include a sudden headache, weakness, numbness, confusion, and difficulty speaking or understanding speech.

diagnoses.name: Optic Neuritis
diagnoses.description: Optic neuritis is inflammation of the optic nerve that can cause a sudden decrease in vision and color blindness, often in just one eye. It can be associated with multiple sclerosis. Other symptoms can include pain with eye movement and, less commonly, flashings lights (photopsias).

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.description: Temporal arteritis, also known as giant cell arteritis, is an inflammation of the blood vessels (usually in the head, especially in the temporal arteries). Symptoms include headaches, jaw pain when chewing, and vision problems. If untreated, it can lead to blindness.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A brain abscess is a collection of pus, immune cells, and other material in the brain, usually from a bacterial or fungal infection. Brain abscesses can cause symptoms similar to a stroke, including headache, weakness on one side of the body, seizures, and speech or vision problems.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic, typically progressive disease involving damage to the sheaths of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, symptoms may include numbness, impairment of speech and of muscular coordination, blurred vision and severe fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves neurological phenomena (aura) like visual disturbances (scotomas) before the actual migraine headache begins.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms such as paralysis or loss of muscle movement (weakness), numbness, or difficulty speaking and understanding speech.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief, temporary disruption of blood supply to part of the brain, spinal cord, or retina, causing stroke-like symptoms such as paralysis or sudden weakness, numbness, and visual problems like scotomas.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes. It mainly affects the legs and feet, leading to numbness, pain, and weakness in these areas.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves, leading to weakness, numbness, and tingling, it can rapidly progress, necessitating emergency medical attention.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Lack of vitamin B12 can lead to neurological difficulties and blood diseases, presenting symptoms such as numbness, weakness, fatigue, and visual disturbances.
A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones, leading to symptoms including fatigue, weakness, and numb sensations.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. Early symptoms may include fever, headache, and fatigue, but it can also cause neurological problems like weakness and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain or the skull vault. Brain tumors can lead to a wide range of symptoms including headache, seizures, paralysis, numbness, and vision problems like scotomas depending on the tumor's location.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic illness involving your central nervous system. The immune system attacks myelin, which is the protective layer around your nerve fibers, leading to delayed response or permanent nerve damage.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraines that involve visual disturbances such as flashes of light, scotomas and sometimes sensory changes including parasthesia.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief period of symptoms similar to those in a stroke. It can cause temporary difficulty with vision, weakness, and parasthesia, but it typically doesn't leave lasting damage.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles responsible for breathing and moving parts of the body, including the arms and legs. It can also lead to dysphagia.

diagnoses.name: Optic Neuritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation that damages the optic nerve, a bundle of nerve fibers that transmits visual information from your eye to your brain. It can cause scotoma and vision issues.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves, leading to weakness, tingling, and paralysis.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: Also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, it affects the nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, leading to loss of muscle control.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain or the skull vault. It can cause a wide range of symptoms depending on its location.

diagnoses.name: Neuromyelitis Optica
diagnoses.description: Also known as Devic's disease, it's an autoimmune disorder where the immune system attacks the optic nerves and spinal cord. It can lead to scotoma and paralysis.

diagnoses: Chemical exposure (e.g., to certain drugs or toxins)

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body including skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs. Symptoms go along with those listed, especially in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: A disease involving abnormal collections of inflammatory cells that form lumps known as granulomas. It commonly affects the lungs but can also affect the skin, causing lichen planus-like eruptions, and may lead to pleural effusion.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and skin rash. Though not common, it may present with features similar to those described.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. It's associated with autoimmune conditions and can lead to symptoms like those mentioned.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause a range of symptoms depending on the organs affected. It might show skin and nasal symptoms as part of its manifestation.

diagnoses.name: Behcet’s Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body, leading to numerous signs and symptoms, including mouth and genital ulcers, and eye inflammation. Skin and nasal involvement is also common.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that provide lubrication to the eyes and mouth. It also can involve other parts of the body, including the skin and lungs, potentially linking to pleural effusion.

diagnoses.name: Lichen Planopilaris
diagnoses.description: A specific form of lichen planus that affects the scalp, leading to nonscarring alopecia. It represents a direct connection to the symptom of nonscarring alopecia.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. While primarily affecting the lungs, it can also manifest extrapulmonary symptoms, including those affecting the skin and mucous membranes.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Wegener's)
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder that causes inflammation of the blood vessels in your nose, sinuses, throat, lungs, and kidneys. It frequently presents with nasal ulcers and can lead to pleural effusions.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.details: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and damage to joints, skin, kidneys, heart, lungs, blood vessels, and brain.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints, causing inflammation, pain, and eventually joint damage.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.details: A group of autoimmune diseases that cause skin and connective tissue to harden and tighten.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.details: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.details: A rare autoimmune disorder that displays features of several connective tissue diseases, such as lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disorder where the body's immune system attacks its own tissues, leading to hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues.

diagnoses.name: Primary Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disorder characterized by thrombosis and pregnancy morbidity in the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies.

diagnoses.name: Undifferentiated Connective Tissue Disease (UCTD)
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disease that presents features typical of several other connective tissue diseases but does not fulfill the criteria for a specific disease.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.details: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, leading to numerous signs and symptoms, notably mouth sores, genital sores, eye inflammation, and skin rashes.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.details: An inflammation of the blood vessels that causes changes in the blood vessel walls, including thickening, weakening, narrowing, and scarring.

diagnoses: Viral infections (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis B/C, Parvovirus B19)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease characterized by inflammation of various parts of the body. It can manifest with skin rashes, joint pain, kidney issues, and hematological disturbances such as hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Dermatitis Herpetiformis
diagnoses.description: A chronic skin condition characterized by blistering, intensely itchy skin. It's associated with gluten sensitivity and can coexist with other autoimmune conditions that may cause hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Bullous Pemphigoid
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that involves the presence of bullous rash and may be associated with other autoimmune hematological conditions like peripheral neuropathy, hemolytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Evan's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by the combination of immune thrombocytopenia and autoimmune hemolytic anemia. Neurological manifestations can occur, though peripheral neuropathy is less common.

diagnoses.name: Pernicious Anemia
diagnoses.description: A decrease in red blood cells when the body can’t absorb enough vitamin B-12. Can lead to neurological complications such as peripheral neuropathy but is less commonly associated with bullous rash and alopecia.

diagnoses.name: Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria
diagnoses.description: A rare, acquired, life-threatening disease of the blood characterized by destruction of red blood cells, bone marrow failure, and thrombosis. Can indirectly lead to peripheral neuropathy but is less commonly associated with skin and hair manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Porphyria Cutanea Tarda
diagnoses.description: A type of porphyria that leads to blistering skin lesions when skin is exposed to sunlight. Hemolytic anemia can occur during attacks. Peripheral neuropathy and thrombocytopenia are less common.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that can attack skin, kidneys, blood cells, heart, and lungs. Hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, bullous rash, and alopecia are possible manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.description: A syndrome with overlapping features of various systemic rheumatic diseases including SLE, scleroderma, and polymyositis. It can include features such as hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, peripheral neuropathy, and skin manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Immune Hemolytic Anemia
diagnoses.description: A form of hemolytic anemia caused by medications. The autoimmune reaction can also lead to thrombocytopenia. Bullous rash and nonscarring alopecia may also occur as drug reactions.

diagnoses: Lupus Nephritis (if renal involvement is considered)
Viral infections (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis C, Epstein-Barr virus)
Peripheral neuropathy of varied etiology (diabetes, nutritional deficiencies, toxin exposure)
Scalp diseases leading to nonscarring alopecia (e.g., Alopecia Areata)
Psychiatric conditions or substance abuse causing delirium
Connective tissue diseases (e.g., Mixed Connective Tissue Disease)
